G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 231, § 1, as the amount in controversy exceeds the District Court’s minimum jurisdictional threshold but does not exceed the statutory limit.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 231, § 1, as the amount in controversy exceeds the District Court’s minimum jurisdictional threshold but does not exceed the statutory limit.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the cause of action arose in this judicial district, and Defendant conducts business and owns property in Lynn, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 26B.proposition: Under G.L. c. 148, § 26B, property owners and managers are required to install and maintain operational smoke detectors in common hallways and living areas of multi‑unit dwellings.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26B, 27.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain operational smoke detectors constitutes negligence under G.L. c. 148, §§ 26B, 27, and 105 C.M.R. 410.482, which impose duties to install and maintain functional fire protection devices.

105 C.M.R. 410.482.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain operational smoke detectors constitutes negligence under G.L. c. 148, §§ 26B, 27, and 105 C.M.R. 410.482, which impose duties to install and maintain functional fire protection devices.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.proposition: In Massachusetts, a landlord must exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas in a safe condition for tenants and lawful occupants.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and adopting a general reasonable-care standard owed by land possessors to lawful entrants. That principle has been applied in Massachusetts to landlords’ duties to tenants and their lawful occupants in common areas. Although the provided excerpt is from a concurrence and does not mention landlords or common areas, the case as a whole supports the broader proposition that possessors of land (including landlords as to common areas they control) must exercise reasonable care to keep premises safe for lawful occupants.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.relevant_excerpt: We therefore hold that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The rigid common law classifications of invitee and licensee and the resulting differences in the degree of care owed are hereby abolished in this Commonwealth. The proper test is whether in the management of his property the occupier has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others….

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 163\u2.proposition: In Massachusetts, a landlord must exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas in a safe condition for tenants and lawful occupants.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 163\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that Massachusetts landlords owe a duty of reasonable care to maintain common passageways and other areas under their control, for the benefit of both tenants and their guests. Although Young v. Garwacki’s main doctrinal change extends negligence liability beyond common areas to demised premises, the Court reaffirms and relies on prior cases (Lindsey and King) that had already established the landlord’s duty of reasonable care regarding common areas. Thus it supports the stated proposition about common areas.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 163\u2.relevant_excerpt: In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that “the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.” Id. at 82. In King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, we extended the landlord’s general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways to include tenants as well as their visitors.

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes a landlord’s liability for injuries resulting from unsafe or defective conditions in common areas that are under the landlord’s control.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common passageways within the landlord’s control to all lawful visitors, including tenants’ guests. It further treats violations of a statutory duty regarding lighting in such common areas as evidence of negligence. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts law recognizes landlord liability for injuries resulting from unsafe or defective conditions in common areas under the landlord’s control.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we no longer follow the common law rule that a landlord owes to his tenants’ visitors the same duty he owes to his tenants concerning the maintenance of common passageways in his control… The landowner’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining property he controls extends to all lawful visitors on his premises, including the lawful visitors of his tenants… If Massios violated a statutory duty concerning safe maintenance of common passageways within her control, such a violation is evidence of negligence which the jury may consider.”

King v. G&M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658,.raw_text: King v. G&M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 659 (1977)
King v. G&M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658,.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes a landlord’s liability for injuries resulting from unsafe or defective conditions in common areas that are under the landlord’s control.
King v. G&M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658,.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
King v. G&M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses and reforms Massachusetts landlord-tenant law regarding common areas. The court expressly adopts the “general, continuing duty” rule and holds that a landlord who retains control over common areas owes tenants (not just their guests) a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep those areas in safe condition. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts law recognizes landlord liability for injuries from unsafe or defective conditions in common areas under the landlord’s control.
King v. G&M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658,.relevant_excerpt:
“We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors…

…[T]he landlord may be viewed as in effect an ‘occupier.’ … [T]he landlord… is subject to liability to his tenant and others lawfully upon the leased property… for physical harm caused by a dangerous condition upon that part of the leased property retained in the landlord’s control, if the landlord by the exercise of reasonable care could have… discovered the condition… and… made the condition safe.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care required of a reasonably prudent property manager under similar circumstances.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not hold or even discuss that the defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care for a reasonably prudent property manager; instead, the court affirms summary judgment for the defendant because plaintiffs failed to prove causation (and, potentially, duty/control). The court specifically notes the absence of any evidence that a defect chargeable to the defendant caused the accident and expressly declines to decide whether a duty of care existed. Thus, the case undercuts rather than supports a claim that the defendant’s conduct breached the applicable standard of care.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. ... Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment."

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: A violation of a statutory duty, such as failure to comply with G.L. c. 148 or local fire safety regulations, constitutes evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The court expressly discusses the effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69 and reaffirms the Massachusetts rule that statutory violations do not constitute negligence per se but are admissible as “some evidence” of negligence. Although the defendant ultimately prevails because the jury found no common-law negligence, the opinion clearly states that a violation of such a statutory duty is evidence relevant to proving negligence, which aligns with the proposition. The case simply emphasizes that this evidence alone is not dispositive.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only 'some evidence' of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968)."

Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.raw_text: Guinan v. Famous Players‑Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501, 516 (1929)
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.proposition: A violation of a statutory duty, such as failure to comply with G.L. c. 148 or local fire safety regulations, constitutes evidence of negligence.
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the evidentiary effect of violating safety regulations issued under statutory authority. The court explicitly states that the fire prevention regulations "have the force and effect of law" and that violation of a statute, ordinance, or regulation is evidence of negligence as to harms the enactment was intended to prevent. This aligns directly with the proposition that failure to comply with G.L. c. 148–type fire safety regulations constitutes evidence of negligence.
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence from which the jury could properly find that the delivery of the scrap film by Doherty to Shirley in a burlap bag was not a safe disposal of it. The regulations have the force and effect of law. A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent. Wright v. Malden & Melrose Railroad, 4 Allen, 283, 290. Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 140. …”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 51–52 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This is a dissenting opinion explicitly rejecting that the defendants’ negligence proximately caused the plaintiff’s injuries. The dissent argues the evidence was speculative and insufficient on causation and that defendants were entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Although the majority in Mullins did find causation, the quoted text itself does not support the proposition; it undermines it.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion in Jupin v. Kask is focused on whether the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care and whether summary judgment should be reversed so a jury can decide negligence issues. The court does not hold that the defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing the plaintiff’s injuries; instead, it expressly leaves questions of breach and causation for the jury. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing the injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Plaintiff’s smoke inhalation, medical expenses, lost wages, and property losses were the foreseeable and direct results of Defendant’s failure to maintain fire safety equipment.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence indicates that the court concluded the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the plaintiff’s smoke inhalation, medical expenses, lost wages, and property losses were foreseeable and directly caused by the defendant’s failure to maintain fire safety equipment. Thus, this case undercuts rather than supports the proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: As a further matter, Defendant’s negligent conduct constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability as recognized in Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973), evidence of negligence and failure to maintain habitable premises.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Hemingway (a concurrence/dissent) discusses implied warranty of habitability as a contractual obligation tied to compliance with statutes and the State Sanitary Code, and distinguishes that concept from common‑law negligence. It does not state that negligent conduct itself constitutes a breach of the implied warranty or that breach of the implied warranty is evidence of negligence. Accordingly, using this case for the specific proposition that defendant’s negligent conduct is a breach of the implied warranty and evidence of negligence is inaccurate.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally, (b) that if he rented the unit without correcting the violations the statutes did not per se impose an obligation on him for the benefit of the tenant to correct the violations, and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations and if he wanted them corrected the burden of doing so was on him.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261, § 1;

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 1.proposition: Award Plaintiff interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261, § 1;

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
